section10.title: Creating your own widget in Shiny
section10.paragraph1: In the context of industrializing a web application, the standard inputs provided by Shiny are clearly not visually sufficient, especially when trying to follow the company's design guidelines.
section10.paragraph2: Here are both versions for comparison:
section10.paragraph3: No surprise, the input designed in the mockup fits better into the DIGITAL FUEL CAPITAL visual universe.
section10.paragraph4: To change the appearance of an input in a Shiny application, there are mainly two methods:

method1.label: 1. The quick & dirty method:
method1.text: This involves directly overriding the default style of a standard Shiny input. It's useful when you need to quickly tweak some minor adjustments.

method2.label: 2. The professional method:
method2.text: This involves developing a custom widget from scratch. It's more complex, but it allows for complete and integrated customization.

paragraph5.text: A good starting point for the
paragraph5.text2: is to use the code inspector to temporarily adjust the visual style until you achieve the desired look. Then, you would simply add these styles to the header of your Shiny application.

section10.paragraph6: The professional method, on the other hand, requires a bit more work. It involves creating a fully customized Shiny widget using basic HTML, CSS, and JavaScript components. This allows for total control over the widget's behavior and appearance, with the added benefit of increased reusability and maintainability.
